New Records: The Chicago White Sox surpassed the modern-day mark of 120 losses held by the expansion 1962 New York Mets by suffering their 121st defeat on September 28, 2024, against the Detroit Tigers.
Key Match Events: Sean Burke followed a 2-hour, 20-minute rain delay with five scoreless innings, allowing two hits, striking out six and walking three.
Bryan Ramos hit a solo home run, and Andrew Benintendi hit a two-run home run in the eighth inning, which was his 20th of the season and matched a career high.
Pre-Game Insights: The White Sox were aware that the national media would focus on their record-breaking losses and prepared to stay together and improve every single day.
Post-Match Reflections: Grady Sizemore, the interim manager, said that the players showed a lot this year and that it's not the year they wanted, but they can build from this and learn from it.
Nicky Lopez said that the team came every single day and worked, and it wasn't due to a lack of effort, but rather a year where they couldn't figure it out.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The White Sox topped the Tigers 4-0 on Saturday in front of a sellout crowd of 41,933, just their second victory in 12 chances in the season series.
Others: The White Sox will go down in history as the team with the modern record for most losses, but the players will remember their teammates as a group that stayed together through a lot.
